definitions: having been given a particular shape through molding or arranging
brought into existence through organization or systematic planning
having reached a state of full physical or mental development
examples: The artist created a perfectly formed sculpture from clay
These newly formed clouds suggest rain is coming
The recently formed committee will meet next Monday
Their formed alliance proved crucial during negotiations
His fully formed opinions rarely changed with new evidence
The child's formed personality showed remarkable confidence

definitions: of or containing formic acid, a colorless corrosive liquid found naturally
pertaining to or derived from ants, especially their chemical secretions
examples: The laboratory uses formic acid for various chemical reactions
Formic compounds are important in organic chemistry synthesis
The formic secretions from ants can cause skin irritation
Scientists study formic communication patterns in ant colonies

definitions: inspiring fear or respect through being impressively powerful, capable, or intense
requiring serious effort to overcome, defeat, or deal with successfully
examples: She faced a formidable opponent in the championship finals
The castle's formidable walls deterred many invaders
Learning Mandarin presents a formidable challenge for English speakers
The company faces formidable competition from tech giants

definitions: without a clear or definite shape, structure, or arrangement
lacking organization, coherent structure, or systematic arrangement in ideas
examples: A formless mass of clay awaited the sculptor's touch
The formless clouds drifted lazily across the sky
His formless thoughts needed organizing before the presentation
The essay was formless and difficult to follow

definitions: produced according to a formula or set pattern, especially in a mechanical way
lacking originality or individuality by following predictable patterns or conventions
examples: The formulaic approach to solving these equations saves time
Their formulaic response to complaints never varies
Most romantic comedies follow a formulaic plot structure
His formulaic writing style lacks creative expression

definitions: created or prepared according to a systematic plan or formula
expressed in a clear and precise way using careful thought
examples: The carefully formulated strategy led to business success
They followed a formulated plan for emergency evacuations
Her formulated response addressed all the committee's concerns
The formulated theory explained the phenomenon perfectly

definitions: played loudly and with force in musical performance
something at which a person excels or has special ability
examples: The conductor signaled for a forte passage in the symphony
The forte sections contrasted beautifully with the pianissimo
Mathematics has always been her forte in academics
Public speaking is definitely not his forte

definitions: about to happen or appear in the near future
willing to give information or to talk openly and honestly
ready or made available when needed or wanted
examples: Details about the forthcoming election will be announced tomorrow
Her forthcoming book explores climate change solutions
He wasn't very forthcoming about his plans for retirement
The witness was forthcoming with crucial evidence
Financial support was not forthcoming from the government
Help was forthcoming from unexpected sources

definitions: direct and outspoken in manner or speech without hesitation or evasion
examples: Her forthright criticism helped improve the project significantly
I appreciate your forthright approach to difficult conversations
The manager's forthright manner sometimes offended sensitive employees
He gave a forthright assessment of the company's problems

definitions: constituting number forty in a sequence or being one of forty equal parts
examples: They celebrated their fortieth wedding anniversary last weekend
This is the fortieth edition of the annual report
She finished in fortieth place in the marathon
The fortieth day marked an important milestone

definitions: strengthened with defensive works to protect against attack
having vitamins or minerals added to increase nutritional value
made stronger emotionally or mentally to face difficulties
examples: The fortified castle withstood numerous sieges throughout history
Troops occupied the fortified positions along the border
Children benefit from drinking fortified milk with vitamin D
The fortified cereal provides essential daily nutrients
She felt fortified by her friends' encouragement and support
The team was fortified by their recent victory

definitions: happening or produced once every two weeks or fourteen days
examples: The fortnightly meetings keep everyone updated on progress
She receives her fortnightly paycheck every other Friday
Our fortnightly newsletter reaches thousands of subscribers worldwide
The fortnightly garbage collection schedule starts next month

definitions: happening by accident or chance rather than design or intention
happening by a lucky chance that brings unexpected good fortune
examples: Their fortuitous meeting at the conference changed both careers
The timing of the discovery was entirely fortuitous
A fortuitous rain shower saved the drought-stricken crops
His fortuitous investment doubled in value overnight

definitions: favored by or involving good luck or fortune; lucky and advantageous
examples: We were fortunate to find shelter before the storm
She's fortunate to have such supportive parents
The fortunate timing allowed us to catch the last train
It was fortunate that nobody was injured

definitions: the cardinal number equal to four times ten or four decades
examples: Forty students enrolled in the advanced physics course
The temperature reached forty degrees Celsius yesterday
She owns forty pairs of designer shoes
The journey takes approximately forty minutes by car

definitions: relating to or denoting the remains of prehistoric organisms preserved in rock
extremely old-fashioned or outdated in attitudes, ideas, or practices
examples: The fossil record provides evidence of ancient life forms
Scientists discovered fossil remains of a new dinosaur species
His fossil ideas about technology hinder company progress
Don't be such a fossil about modern music

definitions: converted into a fossil through geological processes over time
made rigid, fixed, or incapable of change like outdated institutions
examples: The fossilised bones were millions of years old
Fossilised tree resin becomes amber over time
The fossilised bureaucracy resists all attempts at reform
Their fossilised traditions prevent social progress

definitions: converted into a fossil through geological processes over time
made rigid, fixed, or incapable of change like outdated institutions
examples: The fossilized footprints revealed ancient migration patterns
Fossilized plants provide clues about prehistoric climates
His fossilized thinking prevents innovation in the department
The company's fossilized policies need complete overhaul

definitions: providing parental care for children not one's own by birth
encouraging or promoting the development or growth of something
examples: The foster parents provided a loving home for three children
She grew up in several foster homes during childhood
The program aims to foster creativity in young artists
Good communication fosters trust between team members

definitions: having an extremely unpleasant smell, taste, or appearance
morally offensive, wicked, or obscene in nature or character
contrary to the rules or contrary to what is acceptable
examples: The foul odor from the garbage made everyone nauseous
The water had a foul taste after sitting overnight
His foul language shocked everyone at the formal dinner
Such foul behavior will not be tolerated here
The referee called a foul play during the match
That was a foul move in the chess game

definitions: made dirty, polluted, or contaminated with harmful substances
tangled, caught, or obstructed in ropes, lines, or machinery
examples: The fouled water supply caused widespread illness
Oil spills have fouled miles of pristine coastline
The fouled anchor chain prevented the ship from moving
His fishing line became fouled in underwater debris

definitions: discovered after being lost or discovered for the first time
established or set up through deliberate action or planning
examples: The found treasure was worth millions of dollars
Police returned the found wallet to its owner
The found principles guide our organization's mission today
Their found company became a global success

definitions: the cardinal number between three and five; one more than three
examples: Four seasons make up a complete year cycle
The table has four legs for stability
She owns four cats and two dogs
The meeting is scheduled for four o'clock

definitions: four times as great or as numerous as something else
consisting of four parts, elements, or aspects combined
examples: Sales showed a fourfold increase over last quarter
The population experienced fourfold growth in two decades
Their fourfold strategy addresses all major concerns
The fourfold path leads to enlightenment

definitions: firm and resolute in purpose or belief without wavering
having four sides of equal length forming a square shape
examples: She stands foursquare behind her controversial decision
The company remains foursquare in its commitment to quality
The foursquare design of the building symbolizes stability
They built a foursquare fortress on the hill

definitions: the cardinal number equal to thirteen plus one or two times seven
examples: Fourteen students signed up for the field trip
The recipe requires fourteen ounces of flour
She'll be fourteen years old next month
The bus arrives every fourteen minutes

definitions: constituting number fourteen in a sequence or one of fourteen equal parts
examples: The fourteenth amendment guarantees equal protection under law
Today marks their fourteenth year in business
She finished in fourteenth place in the competition
The fourteenth century saw significant cultural changes

definitions: constituting number four in a sequence or one of four equal parts
examples: The fourth quarter showed improved sales figures
She came in fourth place in the race
July fourth is Independence Day in the United States
This is the fourth time I've explained this

definitions: cunning and sly in manner like a fox; crafty or wily
sexually attractive in a bold or obvious way, especially of women
examples: His foxy business tactics always keep competitors guessing
She gave a foxy smile that hinted at secrets
The foxy actress turned heads at the premiere
That dress makes you look absolutely foxy tonight

definitions: constituting a very small part or amount of something whole
relating to or expressed as a mathematical fraction or fractions
examples: The improvement showed only fractional gains this quarter
There was a fractional pause before she answered
Students learn fractional arithmetic in elementary mathematics
The fractional distillation process separates oil components

definitions: irritable and quarrelsome; inclined to make trouble or be uncooperative
examples: The fractious toddler refused to take a nap
Dealing with fractious customers requires patience and skill
The fractious debate lasted well into the night
Team meetings became fractious over budget disagreements

definitions: easily broken, shattered, or damaged requiring careful handling
emotionally vulnerable or easily upset requiring gentle treatment
easily destroyed or threatened requiring careful preservation or handling
examples: Handle the fragile glassware with extreme care
The fragile antique vase shattered when dropped
She's still fragile after the traumatic experience
His fragile ego couldn't handle any criticism
The fragile peace agreement could collapse at any moment
The ecosystem remains fragile despite conservation efforts

definitions: consisting of small disconnected or incomplete parts rather than a whole
examples: The archaeologists found only fragmentary evidence of the civilization
Her fragmentary memories of childhood puzzled therapists
The report provides only fragmentary information about the incident
Fragmentary records make historical research challenging

definitions: broken or separated into disconnected parts or groups lacking unity
examples: The fragmented mirror reflected distorted images
Modern society has become increasingly fragmented
The fragmented hard drive lost important data
Their fragmented approach to problem-solving proved ineffective

definitions: having a pleasant or sweet smell that appeals to the senses
examples: The fragrant roses filled the garden with perfume
She prepared fragrant jasmine tea for her guests
The fragrant spices made the kitchen smell wonderful
Fragrant candles created a relaxing atmosphere

definitions: physically weak and delicate especially due to age or illness
weak and vulnerable; easily broken or destroyed
examples: The frail elderly woman needed assistance walking
His frail health prevented him from traveling
The frail wooden bridge couldn't support heavy traffic
Their frail alliance broke under political pressure

definitions: enclosed in a frame for display or structural support
falsely incriminated or set up to appear guilty of something
examples: The framed photograph hung prominently on the wall
Her framed diploma proved her qualifications
He claimed he was framed for the robbery
The detective suspected the suspect had been framed

definitions: open, honest, and direct in speech or writing, especially when dealing with unpalatable matters
examples: I appreciate your frank assessment of my performance
Let me be frank about the company's financial situation
Her frank manner sometimes offends sensitive people
The doctor was frank about the patient's prognosis

definitions: wild or distraught with fear, anxiety, or other emotion
conducted in a hurried, excited, and chaotic manner
examples: The frantic mother searched everywhere for her missing child
His frantic cries for help echoed through the building
The frantic pace of modern life causes stress
They made frantic preparations before the storm arrived

definitions: of or like a brother or brothers; showing brotherly feelings
relating to or denoting an organization for people sharing interests
examples: The fraternal bond between the soldiers lasted a lifetime
He offered fraternal advice to his younger colleague
She joined a fraternal organization for professional women
The fraternal society provides insurance to members

definitions: obtained, done by, or involving deception, especially criminal deception
examples: The fraudulent documents fooled investigators for months
She was convicted of fraudulent business practices
His fraudulent claim for insurance was eventually exposed
The company engaged in fraudulent accounting methods

definitions: filled with or destined to result in something undesirable
causing or affected by great anxiety or stress
examples: The negotiations were fraught with difficulties
Their relationship was fraught with misunderstandings
The fraught atmosphere made everyone uncomfortable
It was a fraught moment waiting for test results

definitions: unraveled or worn at the edge, typically through age or wear
showing signs of strain or tension especially in relationships
examples: The frayed rope could snap at any moment
Her frayed jacket showed years of constant wear
Tempers were frayed after hours of heated debate
Their frayed relationship finally ended in divorce

definitions: very unusual, strange, or unexpected in a way that might be frightening or unsettling
examples: That was a freaky coincidence meeting you here
The freaky weather patterns worried climate scientists
His freaky behavior at the party concerned everyone
She had a freaky dream about flying fish

definitions: able to act or be done as one wishes; not under control
given or available without charge or payment
not occupied or in use; available for a purpose
not containing or affected by something undesirable
examples: Citizens fought to remain free from oppression
She felt free to express her opinions openly
The museum offers free admission on Sundays
They received free samples at the store
Are you free for lunch tomorrow afternoon?
This parking space is free if you need it
The products are free from artificial preservatives
He's finally free from debt

definitions: born into a condition of freedom rather than slavery or serfdom
examples: Every freeborn citizen had the right to vote
The freeborn population enjoyed more privileges
He stood proud as a freeborn Englishman
Freeborn children attended different schools

definitions: drawn or done by hand without guiding instruments, measurements, or tracings
examples: The architect sketched a freehand drawing of the building
Her freehand calligraphy was remarkably precise
Students practiced freehand sketching in art class
The freehand design showed artistic spontaneity

definitions: working for different companies at different times rather than permanently employed
examples: The freelance writer works from home
She hired a freelance photographer for the event
Many journalists prefer freelance work for flexibility
The company uses freelance designers for special projects

definitions: not attached to or supported by another structure; self-supporting
examples: The freestanding sculpture dominated the gallery space
They installed a freestanding bathtub in the bathroom
The freestanding garage was built behind the house
This freestanding unit doesn't require wall mounting

definitions: acting without restraint or concern for rules, conventions, or consequences
examples: The freewheeling discussion covered controversial topics openly
His freewheeling lifestyle worried his conservative parents
The freewheeling atmosphere encouraged creative thinking
Their freewheeling approach to business broke industry norms
